text:
CORNELIA MAXINE CARDELLO ISLAM:
Since 9/11 we haven't
really learned anything.

I just remember sitting there in
shock and thinking about is

this what it's like
to be at war?

YIM KWONG: I learned that
actually the American people,

we get stronger because
of our diversity.

When I travel through the little
towns upstate, I see
everybody have American flags.
And that's something.

You go by, you feel like, wow,
we're all pulling together.

PATRICIA O'CONE: I was on the
track of everything's OK, it's
a normal day.

Somebody pushed me and
I was like what?
What a jerk.
Who's pushing me today?

And as soon as I got outside
there were rocks falling on my

head and policemen, and the
thing that I learned was that

you shouldn't really make
assumptions about people's

motivations without really
understanding the context.

And it was really kind of
strange day to come to that
realization.

I thought a lot about those
people and hoped
that they got out.

DAVID FREEMAN: We're just as
paranoid, if not more.

And there's now a new face to
put our paranoia and fear,

like a Muslim population or
the Muslim community.

I just think we don't really
know how to deal in a

constructive and healthy way
to tragic events like this.

HANNAH TROOBOFF MCCOLUM: You
know, our parents all

remembered the day when
Kennedy was shot.

I think I understood for the
first time the long-term
impact of one event.

And the sort of power
of memory.

AL LUCENTE: One day I was in
the Trade Center when I cut

out of high school with a bunch
of friends and we all

went there to the restaurant
at the Trade Center.
You remember things you did.

We're never going to
see that again now.

LEROY MCKOY: I supposed to
be there on that day.

When I heard that the
building fell, it
really messed with me.

And come to find out who was
behind it was another thing.

I thought at first that
nationality of people could no
longer be trusted.

MARJORIE SINGER: I think it made
us more aware that this
could happen anywhere.
That America is not--

we're as vulnerable
as anybody else!

TINA ATTERBURG: I learned that
we, as Americans, have got to
remember how to be humble.

And I know it changed the
importance of letting loved

ones know how much you
appreciate them.

TABITHA ELLIS: There are bigger
things in the world.

It was the first time that there
were people who didn't
like Americans.

That was definitely one of the
biggest things I learned.

So I became a lot more cautious
and more fearful of

other people and that was
kind of something
I wish didn't happen.

I wish I wasn't so fearful
about things.

But it's what it does when
you're little, it impacts you
quite a bit.
